designations.source: A review of the beetles of Great Britain: Ground Beetles (Carabidae)
designations.source_description: This report was commissioned to update the national status of ground beetles using IUCN methodology for assessing threat. It covers all species of Carabidae in Great Britain, identifying those that are rare and/or under threat as well as non-threatened and non-native species.
designations.reporting_category: Nationally Scarce, Nationally Rare and Other Species
designations.designation: Nationally Scarce. Includes Red Listed taxa
designations.designation_description: Nationally Scarce - Occurring in 16-100 hectads in Great Britain. Includes rare species qualifying under the main IUCN criteria
designations.comments: Recorded from 0 - 15 hectads in the modern period but expected to occur in 16 - 100.

designations.reporting_category: Red listing based on 2001 IUCN guidelines
designations.designation_description: Taxa which do not qualify for Lower Risk (conservation dependent), but which are close to qualifying for Vulnerable. In Britain, this category includes species which occur in 15 or fewer hectads but do not qualify as Critically Endangered, Endangered or Vulnerable.
designations.comments: The 1980s saw a large pulse of records for this species, including from several hectads in its stronghold area on the North York Moors. This has meant a positive Change Index (pre-/post-1970) and a large negative Raw%Change (pre-/post-1980) but both are biased by very uneven recording effort over time. Nevertheless, this could be a declining species. It meets the area requirements under criterion B2 for Endangered (AOO <500 km2) and Vulnerable (AOO <2,000 km2) and is near to the 'Number of locations' threshold for Vulnerable (B2a).
